page.title: 01The History of Much Hadham
page.content: Much Hadham is a village steeped in history. It was mentioned in the Domesday Book as a great deal of the land of Much Hadham was owned by the Bishopric of London. At various times the village has been known as Hadham Magna, Great Hadham and Much Hadham but the name is reputed to have been derived from Hadda and Ham, signifying the village or home of Hadda. The earliest records of Hadham are dated 946, found in the will of the Saxon Queen Aelfleda, wife of King Edmund. She and her sister inherited land at Hadham from their father, an alderman of Essex. They in turn bequeathed this land to the Bishops of London, who built a palace, but the original building no longer stands.
